registration.description: Time to get your badges, t-shirt and hopefully some nice coffee
registration.title: Registration

opening.description: Official start of the conference. Greetings from the organizers, sponsors and partners.
opening.title: GDG DevFest The Netherlands 2017 Opening

party.description: The after party is a great time to have fun and meet new people!
party.title: Afterparty & networking

workshop_0.description: Kotlin is a new and fun way of writing your code for an Android app. If you have not started yet then is the perfect moment to start. In this workshop, together with fellow developers and experts on hand, you can get a boost in your start with Kotlin.
workshop_0.title: Start learning Kotlin for Android

android_0.description: From PostNL to Rijksmuseum, explore the evolution of Android architectures applied to real apps. Discover how we adopted the new Android Architecture Components to build the Rijksmuseum tours app and solve in an elegant way common Android lifecycle issues.
android_0.title: The Android architecture re-evolution: ViewModel & LiveData

android_1.description: In this talk we'll discuss the problems around UI testing - why is it hard to write such tests, how to get started, how to make them part of your CI system. We'll present a recipe for building a scalable framework that makes writing UI tests a pleasure. We'll discuss mocking libraries and ways to build your own testing DSL. Most of the common "gotcha-s" and sources of flakiness will be solved along the way, as well as giving a few best practices.
android_1.title: Zero to Hero in UI testing

android_2.description: Take a dive into a new cross platform SDK from Google to create Android and iOS apps with 1 codebase written in Dart. By creating an App for bettyskitchen.nl
android_2.title: Creating your first flutter app

android_3.description: It turns out there are a lot of things that are similar about learning a human language similar to one you already know and a computer language similar to one you already know. Some things being super-similar provides a huge leg up, but there are plenty of false friends in both types of language, and there are plenty of differences which make you wonder why you ever thought these things were similar in the first place. This is a tale of the triumphs and perils (and eerie similarities) of learning Dutch as a native English speaker and Kotlin as a developer with a good grip on Swift.
android_3.title: Learning A New Language While Learning A New Language

android_4.description: In the Android world we have heard of so many different app architectures already so why not just dump in another one :) In this talk I will introduce a kind of Event Driven architecture. We will discuss what Event Sourcing and CQRS means. We will also see some code examples of how this can be applied to Android using the famous Android Architecture Blueprints example app. We will also see what value it brings and what headaches it could create. Lastly we will briefly see how this can work with our cloud back-end and intelligent Machine Learning systems.
android_4.title: Event Sourcing & CQRS with Android

android_5.description: Creating eye candy animations takes time and effort, but the end result is worth it. To make your life a bit easier, in this talk Ivan will share with you 10 tips he learned while working on all sorts of animations. Those tips will help you break your fear of animations and after this talk, you will have no more excuses.
android_5.title: Stop Running from Animations

cloud_0.description: In this session we'll dive into what the different Google Cloud ML APIs can do. We combine various solutions to get an interesting result. Goal of the session is share what's involved in creating such an application using ML APIs. Live demos is part of the presentation.
cloud_0.title: Building complex, serverless, applications using Google Cloud Platform

cloud_1.description: For too long we've been thinking that one can't have a relational database with transactions that would scale across multiple locations. You know - CAP theorem, speed of light, all these things. Google has changed recently this by releasing Cloud Spanner - a fully managed relational database service with strong consistency and true horizontal scalability. In this session, I'll do a sort of "Spanner 101" thing - explain the technology, how it does what it does, how to use it, where to use it (and where not). Of course, some live demo will be included. Even if you're not into databases that much - feel free to join, your DBA friend will appreciate that later :)
cloud_1.title: Google Cloud Spanner: Going global with relational database

cloud_2.description: Modern application building require different architectural process, and switching to the model of microservices brings the highest value to the application performance, resiliency, security and flexibility.Google is a pioneer in microservices building, with the notable open source Google-born projects, including gRPC, Istio, and of course, Kubernetes. This talk will highlight the principles of microservices building using the described tools and technologies.
cloud_2.title: Building microservices with Kubernetes, gRPC and Istio

cloud_3.description: In some forms of philosophy, it is believed that language determines the scope of human intelligence. If there are no words to express it, it can not be understood. On the web, this is something that is known for quite some time. The Semantic Web, coined by Tim Berners-Lee, was a first and important step in gathering the vast amount of knowledge available on the web. In this talk, we will look not only at the digital but the physical. How can the Internet of Things help us to create a knowledge repository to understand the world? How can we use tools like the cloud (GCP), graph-databases and schema.org (Google’s RDF-IoT extension) and what can we learn from social networks like Facebook and Google+ to truly understand our world. We will look at classical IoT and new forms of IoT. 'Devices are so 2017, the future is a semantic Internet of Things'
cloud_3.title: A Semantic Internet of Things

cloud_4.description: Microservices are the new-kid-on-the-block… Relatively new at least... Working with microservices and how to deploy them introduced a lot of challenges for the platform. Deploying a single ear on bare-metal was easy but deploying a whole cloud of microservices is not feasible that way. This is why cloud management tools like Kubernetes are being developed. This talk is about what Kubernetes is and how the components like docker, etcd and flannel operate together. I will talk shortly about what debugging possibilities there are in case the platform does not do what you tried to persuade it to do.
cloud_4.title: The Internals Of Kubernetes

cloud_5.description: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) have many successful variants (e.g., LeNet, AlexNet, VGG, GoogLeNet (InceptionV1, V2, V3, V4), Xception, and MobileNet). All of them were originally applied to processing 2D data like images. It remains unknown whether they can be easily modified to process 1D data. This study shows that, with minor modifications, the VGG model can be used to process accelerometer data which is 1D. We trained three VGG models (for different input length) using labeled accelerometer data, in order to detect daily activities (e.g., cycling, driving, jogging, walking, sitting on the train, and sleeping). All our trained models achieved 98% accuracy. More details of this study include: (1) data pre-processing (streaming, shuffling, augmentation); (3) activation function; (4) loss function; (5)  GPU computing; (6) Dutch supercomputer for training large scale model; and (7) Google cloud services (storage and virtual machine).
cloud_5.title: Detecting activity patterns on accelerometer data: a Deep Learning approach using Google Cloud

web_0.description: In this session we'll dive into what the different Google Cloud ML APIs can do. We combine various solutions to get an interesting result. Goal of the session is share what's involved in creating such an application using ML APIs. Live demos is part of the presentation.
web_0.title: Machine Learning APIs and how to get the most of it

web_1.description: What is the first thing that comes to your mind when you are starting to develop your product? You need to think about all sort of features. How you are going to grow your app. Engage your audience and make money in the process, right? What if you could choose a platform to build your app with confidence, without the need of managing infrastructure, trusted by companies like The New York Times, The Economist, Shazam and much more. Firebase gives you the tools and infrastructure you need to build better apps and grow businesses. Join this talk and learn how to overcome the challenges of build extraordinary web apps using Firebase.
web_1.title: Let Firebase help you to build better Web apps

web_2.description: The talk covers an introduction to Tensorflow main functioning and covers a wide variety of cases of use including images, raw data and approach to neural net design . It focuses on NASA SPACE APPS CHALLENGE 2016 Global finalist project for Asteroid detection and limbic system design.
web_2.title: TensorFlow : Cases of use

web_3.description: Time for JavaScript to get physical. With WebBluetooth the Chrome browser can actually take control of all kinds of physical devices in the real world like lightbulbs, robots and even drones. And nowadays you can even run JavaScript straight on microcontrollers and even little Bluetooth beacons. This talk will teach you the basics that you need to get started and give a peek at some more advanced topics like building your own Bluetooth devices using just JavaScript.
web_3.title: Having fun with JavaScript and Bluetooth

web_4.description: Many developers starting out with TensorFlow will say it has a very steep learning curve. Why is this the case? In my talk I will argue that it is because TensorFlow is at the heart of three distinct disciplines: Computer Science, Artificial Intelligence and Mathematics. To truly build sensible programs with Tensorflow, one has to be familiar with at least the basics of each of these disciplines. In my talk I will start out with ideas from Artificial Intelligence, translate this to the realm of mathematics, and finally show how one could implement this on the computer with TensorFlow.
web_4.title: TensorFlow: Making sense of it

web_5.description: Applications that require data from real time events (such as a chat application, car position updates when you order an Uber, the stock market prices) impose their own challenges. How to store data? Can you cache data at all? How to make sure data that is constantly changing is consistent throughout the app? We’ll share our own experience at BUX on designing and coming up with an architecture to deal with these issues.
web_5.title: Designing a real-time data application: a case study on the stock market
